ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
-Different kinds of separation mechanisms
-Thermodynamics
-Useful methods for calculating things having to do with separations and purifications
I learned mostly about separation techniques and distillation.
I learned a lot about different separation and purification processes.
Principles of separation and purification processes, a necessary knowledge for prospective chemical engineers.
I learned about distillation, absorption, phase diagrams, and liquid-liquid extractions. I learned about design and quantification of separation and purification processes.
I learned how to separate and purify processes.
I learned about various separation processes such as distillation and absorption. I also reviewed key concepts from physical chemistry, thermodynamics, transport phenomena, and kinetics.
I learned many skills in the methods of separations of chemicals.
An overview of what "separation" means and techniques in separation.
Separation  and purification processes  for different systems and phases as well as applications in engineering.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Stengths
-low workload
-nice professor
-tests on material we actually learned

Weaknesses
-somewhat disorganized
-lectures felt repetitive
This course was relatively low workload. I also enjoyed the material that we covered. I think that it could have been slightly more engaging.

The course does not cover a large amount of material for better or for worse. Most of what was covered was a review. The lectures were often disorganized and required a high level of engagement to be able to understand what was going on. The lecture notes were done well and super helpful. The PSETs were short and covered relevant material.
I found having Professor Zhong's posted on canvas was very helpful.

Mingjiang is an amazing professor, he cares about students learning the material thoroughly over pushing through with what he planned for in the syllabus. He takes into account what is important to know and what is less important from the textbook material and also includes useful knowledge about what to expect in working at an industry setting.

Strengths - lecture notes, recitation sessions, clear explanations from the professor 
Weaknesses - we deviated a lot from the syllabus in terms of timing and the final exam had problems of a type that we had never done before, nor were we told to watch out for

Strengths: I felt that lectures were pretty comprehensible, given our background. The course was also educational, but not too strenuous, so I overall really enjoyed it.
Weaknesses: The course was not very well structured. We were supposed to have six problem sets, but were only assigned four (one of which was due a week after the final!). I usually am all in favor of less homework, but we did close to no examples in class, so I felt pretty unprepared to solve problems on the exams. The midterm was pretty fair, but the choices of problems for the final were not representative of what we learned in class. Still, the grading was very generous, so that made up for it.
This class is pretty well taught, but a deviation from the text book would be helpful.

Strengths: Professor tries really hard to make sure everyone is accommodated for. It is also arguably the most applied class to date, which is actually refreshing for the major. Weaknesses: I think the content swings between being very hard and very easy.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If it's required for the major or you're looking for an easier engineering class
I would recommend this course to another student, but its not very useful unless you are a chemical engineer.
If you are interested in separation processes, then yes. Workload is very manageable.

It's a staple chemical engineering class, and I did learn a lot. The professor offered really good explanations and clarifications, as did the TA. There were a lot of curveballs on the exams, which can be disorienting, but the grading takes that into account and is very generous.

I know you. You're a chemical engineering major and you're looking at the course reviews as if it makes a difference because you know that either way you have to take this course but you find some solace in knowing that others have suffered through this major and made it out so you can do it too. Let's face it, no one is looking to take this class because they are interested or because it's fun. Although it doesn't matter that much I'll still give you a little summary. The workload week to week is definitely not as bad as other engineering courses. We ended up having only 4 psets (although it's usually 6), but either way there was a recitation session for them which really helped to complete them properly. The exams were also not too bad and the psets were helpful in exam prep. As far as engineering courses go, this one is not too bad as long as you pay VERY close attention to everything that is said in this class.

There are very few problem sets for this course taught by Prof. Zhong which makes it more difficult to be sufficiently prepared for the exams. The course could have used a little more guided preparation for the skills being tested on the exams.
Only chemical engineering seniors would be taking this course, and it is required. To future seniors: especially if it is better organized when you take it, you won't have too many complaints.
I don't think you should take this class if you are not Chemical Engineering. It is really tailored to the major.
